channel.title: NYT > New York
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Mamdani Vows to Govern ‘Audaciously’ and Protect New York’s Vulnerable
item.description: Zohran Mamdani gave his first public speech as mayor of New York City, after an inauguration that drew tens of thousands of people.
item.dc:creator: Dana Rubinstein
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times

item.title: Mamdani Lays Out Agenda of ‘Affordability and Abundance’ on First Day in Office
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani acknowledged skeptics of his plans while reiterating that he would focus on working-class New Yorkers.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:credit: James Estrin/ The New York Times
item.media:description: Zohran Mamdani, standing with his wife, Rama Duwaji, waves to the crowd outside City Hall at his inauguration ceremony.

item.title: Mamdani’s First Orders Focus on Housing and Undoing Adams’s Decisions
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani signed a flurry of executive orders on his first day as mayor of New York City. They were aimed at protecting tenants and revoking some of ex-Mayor Eric Adams’s past orders.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani signed a series of executive orders to protect tenants at a rent stabilized building in Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Thursday.

item.title: Amid Poetry, Song and the Cold, Mamdani’s Inauguration Evokes Hope
item.description: A communal spectacle, spilling out of City Hall into the streets of Broadway, conveyed how many New Yorkers see the promise in a Zohran Mamdani mayoralty.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: The crowd that filled a stretch of Broadway, south of City Hall in Manhattan, spanned a cross-section of the city’s residents.

item.title: A DJ, a Poet and Politicians Make Up Mamdani’s Inaugural Lineup
item.description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez will deliver opening remarks and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will administer the oath of office.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Democrat of New York, will deliver the opening remarks at Zohran Mamdani’s ceremonial inauguration on Thursday.

item.title: Here’s Why Lucy Dacus Chose ‘Bread and Roses’ for Mamdani’s Inauguration
item.description: The Grammy-winning singer, part of the supergroup boygenius, followed a performance by Mandy Patinkin, who sang “Over the Rainbow.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lucy Dacus during a concert in Queens last year.

item.title: Mayor Zohran Mamdani, at Inauguration, Vows to Represent All New Yorkers
item.description: Mr. Mamdani, the city’s first Muslim and South Asian mayor, celebrated the city’s diversity and pledged to govern “audaciously” in his inaugural address. Hours later, he signed three executive orders related to housing.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times

item.title: Mamdani’s Parents ‘Look Forward to a Joyous Time’
item.description: Mahmood Mamdani and Mira Nair will host an intimate dinner after the festivities following their son’s swearing in ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zohran Mamdani’s parents, Mahmood Mamdani, far left, and Mira Nair, far right, appeared with their son and his wife, Rama Duwaji, at an Election Night watch party in Brooklyn.

item.title: AOC Urges New Yorkers to Celebrate Mamdani’s Inauguration as Their Own
item.description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, speaking at Zohran Mamdani’s inauguration, said that his election represented New Yorkers’ choosing “prosperity for the many over spoils for the few.”
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg

item.title: Mamdani Revokes Executive Orders That Adams Signed to Support Israel
item.description: Former Mayor Eric Adams and some conservative-leaning Jewish leaders criticized the revocation of his executive orders, one of which he signed just last month.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani took office on Thursday.

item.title: Images From the Dawn of the Mamdani Era
item.description: Thousands of New Yorkers packed the plaza ouside City Hall and the streets of Lower Manhattan to see Mayor Zohran Mamdani take office.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of people gathered outside City Hall to see Mayor Zohran Mamdani and his wife, Rama Duwaji, at Mr. Mamdani’s inauguration on Thursday.

item.title: Mamdani Pays Tribute to the Foods That Define and Sustain New York
item.description: In his inaugural address, Mayor Zohran Mamdani invoked the cuisines of New York as metaphors for the city’s diversity, ambitions and promise.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zohran Mamdani dug into the chicken biryani last year at Kabab King in Jackson Heights, Queens, a restaurant he has frequented since high school.

item.title: ‘You Are Worth It’: Jumaane Williams Delivers Powerful Inauguration Speech
item.description: Mr. Williams, New York City’s public advocate, teared up as he addressed a portion of his remarks to his younger self, captivating the crowd.
item.dc:creator: Maya King and Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jumaane Williams has entered his third term as New York’s public advocate, who serves as a watchdog for city government.

item.title: The Full Transcript of Zohran Mamdani’s Inauguration Speech
item.description: New York’s new mayor challenged his supporters and his opponents to make the city better, and to hold him to account.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: “What we achieve together will reach across the five boroughs and it will resonate far beyond,” Mayor Zohran Mamdani told New Yorkers in his inaugural address.

item.title: In his invocation, an imam prays for the success of Mamdani and New York City.
item.dc:creator: Maya King
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Imam Khalid Latif, of the Islamic Center of New York City, was joined onstage by other religious leaders.

item.title: New York Magazine Put Mamdani’s Team on Its Cover. One Aide Was Erased.
item.description: Catherine Almonte Da Costa was part of a photo shoot on the mayor-elect’s inner circle. The next day she resigned amid an uproar over antisemitic statements she had posted on social media years earlier.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman
item.media:credit: Sara Naomi Lewkowicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The latest cover of New York magazine includes a group portrait of Zohran Mamdani and his inner circle. Catherine Almonte Da Costa had stood in the space where the “W” in the magazine logo can now be seen.

item.title: Rama Duwaji Gives ‘Statement Coat’ New Meaning at Mamdani’s Inauguration
item.description: With her chocolate-brown princess-line coat, New York’s new first lady looked a little funky, a little vintage, a little Tolstoy, entirely proper and unlike anyone else on the stage.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rama Duwaji arriving with her husband, Mayor Zohran Mamdani, for his official inauguration ceremony at City Hall on Thursday.

item.title: Mamdani’s home borough of Queens is having its moment in the spotlight.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: In November, Zohran Mamdani introduced his transition team in the shadow of the Unisphere, one of the most recognizable landmarks in his home borough of Queens.

item.title: His name is pronounced zuh-RON mom-DAH-nee. Not everyone gets it.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Benjamin Oreskes and Andy Newman
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A campaign sign for Zohran Mamdani on Staten Island in the summer. He has described the pronunciation of his name, which is frequently mangled, as “pretty phonetic honestly.”

item.title: Revisit our coverage of Mamdani’s upbringing, his activism, his record and his campaign.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zohran Mamdani is the product of the narratives that shaped him as a student, an activist and a politician.

item.title: Mamdani trades a neighborhood that made him mayor for one that backed his opponents.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro and Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gracie Mansion, the home to mayors for generations, boasts 11,000 square feet of living and entertaining space, a spacious backyard perched over the East River and full-time security.

item.title: Eric Adams spent his final hours as mayor out of sight and undermining Mamdani.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Kylie Cooper/Reuters
item.media:description: Former Mayor Eric Adams attended the New Year’s Eve celebration in Times Square on Wednesday night, after vetoing 19 City Council bills during his last hours in office.

item.title: Another first for Mamdani: using the Quran to take the mayoral oath of office.
item.dc:creator: Maya King
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Public Library lent a Quran that belonged to Arturo Schomburg, the Black writer and historian, for the swearing-in of Mayor Zohran Mamdani on Thursday.

item.title: How to Watch Zohran Mamdani’s Inauguration as New York Mayor
item.description: New York City’s new mayor was officially sworn in just after midnight on Thursday. A second public event will take place this afternoon.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman and Dana Rubinstein
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ceremonial inauguration for Mayor Zohran Mamdani will be held at City Hall starting at 1 p.m. on Thursday.

item.title: Mayor Mamdani Appoints a Team of Government Veterans
item.description: Zohran Mamdani has stocked his administration with seasoned officials, in part to allay concerns about his inexperience and left-wing stances.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jessica Tisch will be staying on as Mayor Zohran Mamdani’s police commissioner.

item.title: ‘This is our time’: The poet Cornelius Eady will read an original work at the inauguration.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Cornelius Eady will be the inaugural poet at Zohran Mamdani’s swearing-in ceremony as mayor of New York.

item.title: How New York City miscounted its mayors for more than 300 years.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kenneth Cobb, assistant commissioner of New York City’s records department, examining historical documents at the Municipal Archives earlier this month.

item.title: Mamdani’s rise was swift. Now he faces daunting challenges.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman

item.title: New York to Phase In Protections for Horseshoe Crabs
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul signed legislation that will ultimately ban the catch and biomedical use of the crabs.
item.dc:creator: Jon Hurdle
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A horseshoe crab at Shirley Chisholm State Park in Brooklyn in 2023. New York has joined Connecticut and New Jersey in enacting protections for the species.

item.title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
item.description: This week’s properties are on the Upper West Side, in Carnegie Hill and Cobble Hill.
item.dc:creator: Heather Senison

item.title: Homes for Sale in New York State
item.description: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Great Neck and a three-bedroom in Briarcliff Manor.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Anne Mancuso
